comments.commentBody:
NAFTA and the WTO were publicly sold as "free trade" (such a benign-sounding term) deals but were really intended to free capital to roam the world in search of the greatest returns. Capitalists did enormously well at the expense of workers, their families and their communities, regardless of national borders.

Having been bitten by "free trade" already, people would understandably take a dim view of the TPP-in-waiting - if they knew about it. Which explains "why the silence", not only of the negotiators but of the corporate media. The TPP will further undermine democracy if enacted. Like the earlier agreements, the TPP will effectively give corporations veto power over national economic and environmental policies. The secret negotiations are themselves a bad enough betrayal of democracy; enacting the TPP will be even worse.

MTF, I'm of Welsh descent and I should know the answer to your query, but I believe it's "Evan" if my guess is right?

AND when will this useless -(US-partisan style) - discussion finally stop?

When everybody understands - that one can not fix the problems by "accounting" -(or gambling) tricks? - and still- "the rule" -(or laws) - of "real" economics apply - as there are: Every country who doesn't put all it's cards on "Finances" or a depressing paying service industry will be fine...
as long as we have men in the world that need to debase women and children and enjoy using women and children for their personal pleasure, in whatever form that may take, we will have prostitution.
It's a power thing.

"Yet, in the United States, we typically arrest the victims rather than the pimps or the johns. Rectifying that would be a step toward modern emancipation."

Arresting the johns will prove as ineffective as arresting the prostitutes and arresting the pimps will be only marginally more effective. Prostitution thrives because of poverty and anti-poverty programs have been targeted by conservative Republicans as government handouts creating a welfare state. What we need are more jobs and the Democrats and Republicans disagree strongly on how to create more jobs: more government action versus less government intervention in a free market.

As long as we have widespread unemployment and poverty, we will see prostitution, which Mr. Kristof reasonably equates with slavery.

Exactly, David.

Much of the discussion around prostitution is heavily loaded with emotional baggage that both doesn't bear much relationship to what prostitution is like for volitional, independent escorts, and pays little heed to harm reduction. Puritanism, and the assumption that no one could ever like sex work or find it worth the risks involved, still dominates the debate. That isn't to discount the very real horrors experienced by trafficking victims, but merely to suggest that many of our assumptions about prostitutes who are not trafficking/pimping victims are misplaced.

The act of exchanging sex for money, by itself, is completely neutral. When both parties consent under equal terms to such an exchange, no evil is being inflicted upon anyone. Evil only comes with prostitution when there is not consent and when the agreement isn't made on equal terms, i.e. if the prostitute has been enslaved or has a pimp. You can separate the former from the latter, and likewise change the legality accordingly.

The simple reality is that johns worry as much about getting caught as prostitutes do. If one class of prostitute is legal, and another is not, the overwhelming majority of johns are going to choose to patronize the former. In such a context, a criminal will not be able to make much money from pimping, and will find another enterprise. If all prostitutes are equally illicit however, there's no reason for a john to avoid a pimp's offerings.

Miranda, as a non-Puritan I want to agree with you. People will always want sex services, and licensing and health monitoring are civilized ways to manage the demand. It isn't the sex I have a problem with. It's the selling.

So here's the question I've never found an answer to. Maybe you have. A prostitute differs from a porn star or erotic dancer or even a dominatrix in that the latter three offer a skilled performance for sale, while prostitution seems to me inevitably linked to slavery because the body itself is sold, if only for a limited time. How is renting your body out different from selling it? SIncere question. Some desperate people might be willing to sell themselves into slavery for meals and a place to sleep, but we still make slavery illegal as contrary to the principles of a free society. Choosing to sell yourself—into permanent slavery or temporarily as a prostitute—is the opposite of free.

So in looking at "volitional" prostitutes, we have to define volition. Correct me if I'm wrong, but surely very few prostitutes wouldn't prefer another line of work if it gave them the same income for an equal number of flexible hours. To put it another way, how many prostitutes would choose the career for their daughters? If not, why not?

C:

Certainly from a Kantian/Deontological perspective, we are dealing with a situation in which a rational moral agent is being treated as a means (rent my body for sex) to an end (I want to satisfy my sexual desires). However, pornography is only a difference of degree: use my image to achieve sexual release, while fantasizing about how you would use me were we to actually meet. So is all sex work unacceptable then? I don't think it is.

While the Deontological arguments against sex work and pornography are compelling, I ultimately find them unsatisfying. The dissatisfaction stems from the fact that sex work is, for me at least, actually quite enjoyable (yes, I am an escort/adult entertainer/porn performer, if you haven't figured it out by now). Pleasure isn't the measure of moral worth, but it's awfully hard to feel like I'm just being used or rented, when the experience is as enjoyable for me as it is the client. Likewise, the service which is provided to a client is often more than sex. Yes, sex is the first principle of prostitution, but based upon the conversations I have with my clients, there is some deeper emotional want that is being satisfied beyond the simple desire to orgasm. I don't have a complete answer for you, but sex work, to me, feels less like renting myself than providing entertainment, pleasure, and even therapy. Would I have sought out the men who see me if they weren't paying? Probably not, but I'm awfully glad I've gotten to meet many of them.

Like the last time you addressed this topic, I disagree that going after johns is the way to end trafficking. Likewise, your characterization of sex work being dominated by pimps and traffickers is at odds with your mention of Backpage. The internet, in sites like Backpage, Eros Guide, and My Red Book, has largely made pimps irrelevant to escorting and prostitution. Sex workers are able to advertise, promote their brand, screen clients, share blacklists, etc. with nothing more than a PC and an internet connection. Since no volitional escort/prostitute has need of a pimp, that means the only prostitutes involved with pimps are those who are being exploited, trafficked or enslaved. The solution then is simple: legalize prostitution, issuing licenses to pimp-free prostitutes/escorts, while increasing the penalties for pimps and for johns who see unlicensed, i.e. exploited or trafficked, prostitutes. The simple reality is the demand for sex workers isn't going to go away -- it's already illegal to solicit a prostitute and yet the demand is still there. Instead, work under the assumption that the demand is going to be there, but change incentive structures so that johns choose licensed, volitional prostitutes over the unlicensed and exploited.

Your "solution" doesn't fix the problem -- we already punish pimps and johns more severely than providers, even if the latter get arrested more -- and has the side effect of killing the livelihood of volitional sex workers.

Hmm, I wonder.  Weren't there people who had similar sentiments when Obama got elected, that they will finally get theirs, that Obama had some fund somewhere to get them houses, whatever they wanted?  I remember some woman interviewed on television who believed she was going to get money off of some  proverbial federal money tree.  Something tells me this is not just one person.

I sincerely doubt that poor families in NY or any other city, expects populism and Socialistic policies to turn them into millionaires overnight.
If that were the case, it would have been done already.
But for those families who live from paycheck to paycheck, a reduction in taxes and an extra $100.00 per pay period, makes a huge difference in their quality of life. That's an extra $2400.00 a year.
It's difficult for idiotic mean-spirited millionaires to understand this dynamic.
I read all this drivel from people whose tax rate is a whopping 15% on capital gains.
The Romneys of the world come to mind.
Poor people do not expect a government hand out.
What they exprct is sensible government policies that will keep the door open to new opportunities like their wealthy counterparts.

It's not a "penalty." It's a "tax."
It's not a "prayer." It's an "invocation."
Those weasels can rationalize anything.
Plenty of important constitutional law decisions deal with "small" local matters.  Or "small" issues like one interracial couple wanting to be married.

Twenty dollars too high.
Are you saying Christie has no class?

In the Virginia race, there should be a greater examination as to why a third candidate got such a high percentage of the votes. Seven percent is a pretty good showing. I am curious to know if most of the votes were out of disgust of the candidates the parties presented them with or did they truly believe in the third party candidate? A person I know in Virginia who normally votes for Democrats voted for the third party candidate as he wanted to send a message to both parties that they need to do better. My guess is that opinions like that are a large part of why the guy got seven percent of the votes. Both parties should be paying attention to this.

Too Joizy? What does that mean? If you're trying to say Jersey, I have spent more than half my life there and no one I know speaks with such an accent. In fact, there is no discernible NJ accent...even the Governor speaks with no accent. Bluster, yes. Accent, no.

In fact, if there is a "Jersey" accent or stereotype, it resides ironically in a small sliver of the state closest to NY. So NY'rs, when you're playfully criticizing NJ, your actually criticizing yourself. And we'd appreciate it if you'd just stop it. Thanks.

Chris Christie will be nominated when pigs fly. He too Joizy and a master of knowing where his self interest lies. He is a basic ultra conservative, a bully, a loud mouth and believes his own propaganda and picks on the powerless. What made him, Sandy, will be his undoing.

By cooperating with the president he obtained a truck load of federal cash which he promised to use to rebuild the homes of the working and middle class in shore communities. A year after Sandy most of those people have not been helped, while only 36% of that money has been spent. Victims are suing and Christie will not account for what was spent and why it was not applied to help the victims he agreed to benefit. Christie is stonewalling he but cannot hide the federal cash while running on the spirit of Sandy.

As to Cucchinelli the story is that he really won a victory against the ACA because the election was so close. I keep hearing this close election meme, but the fact is that the Democrat won in spite of extensive voter suppression and a last minute purge of the voter rolls to disenfranchise potential Democratic voters.

To the margin of victory we should consider how many who would have voted Democratic if their vote was not stolen. There is a message in 2113 for Democrats: iif people come out to vote in good numbers Democrats will win. Republicans must suppress the vote. Not voting is a vote for the Republicans.

By prohibiting TARP loans, didn't Congress simply remove an effective tool to prop up big banks in a financial process?  Won't Congress have to repeal the prohibition in haste when the next financial crisis occurs?  Wouldn't the most effective measure be to claw back all bonuses when the government must bail out banks and require all salary and pay provisions to be capped at Federal government levels?  Certainly bankers would be much careful about managing risk.

This production showed promise and inventiveness, despite the whole awkward subtitling approach, until the horribly ill-conceived and poorly written (or translated?) scene with Stockman's speech, which the company decided to open up to the audience for responses. Besides killing the momentum of the play, it served as an unintentionally hilarious forum for a bunch of self-righteous Brooklynites to give vent to everything from the Gowanus Canal to Monsanto. It felt like high school, and made me embarrassed to live in Brooklyn. The play never recovered.

A great evening and amazing performance by Billy Crystal. He plays a host of characters (mostly family members) and he didn't miss a beat!
It was hysterical and poignant. If you still can, you should get a ticket!
It's worth every penny!
